channel.title: AMD or Intel?
channel.description:
So I posted my configuration on the Gamespot forums to see what the people thought over there. A few people suggested that I change the motherboard and processor to AMD and get a better graphics card. They said that although the i7 is better than the AMD equivalent, it doesn't improve anything when it comes to gaming.
Should I change over to AMD and get a 5970 instead of the 5870?
i7 build: [img]http://img269.imageshack.us/img269/9317/61453661.png[/img]
Total Price ~ $1853.30
Phenom II build: [img]http://img291.imageshack.us/img291/8935/47421223.png[/img]
Total Price $1894.40
The prices don't include the PSU.

item.title: AMD or Intel?
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:35, topic:344895”][quote author=RXVL link=topic=441271.msg3247713#msg3247713 date=1277501532]
Well, firstly, you can cross intel off your list, the new i7 infrastructure is dick. Why? Because everything in computers is based off two. Binary (Base 2), PCI Express x16 (2^4), 32 and 64 bit operating systems (2^5, 2^6), CPU and HD caches, RAM sticks, pretty much everything up until now. Now they throw three sticks of RAM into the equation, 3 is not a binary or base 2 number. It doesn’t make sense to me, everything I’ve learned about computing is based off two, it makes sense. Yes or No, not Yes, No, or Maybe.

Secondly, that AMD build is stupid because he’s using 3 sticks of RAM on a board that’s clearly designed for 2 or 4 RAM sticks. Two of the sticks will run dual channel and the other will be running single channel. I would go with 4 or 8 GB’s of Corsair XMS because a binary number of sticks interact better with each other. Also, overkill on that single GFX, If you’re looking for bitchin’ graphics I’d get a different ASUS motherboard that would support a Crossfire setup and get two ~$400 cards. Go with a better case too, you’ll need the airflow. Antec 900 or 1200.
[/quote]

Sorry but…

Antec 900
Crossfire

HAHAHAHAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHHAHAH

I barely have enough room for a single, albeit long card, and even then I had to remove the optional fan for one of the harddrive bays and I can only fit 3 harddrives in or 4 if I do some fuckery with the cables.[/quote]

Lemme mod it and ill get it to fit

Read full topic

Binary (Base 2), PCI Express x16 (2^4), 32 and 64 bit operating systems (2^5, 2^6), CPU and HD caches, RAM sticks, pretty much everything up until now. Now they throw three sticks of RAM into the equation, 3 is not a binary or base 2 number. It doesn’t make sense to me, everything I’ve learned about computing is based off two, it makes sense. Yes or No, not Yes, No, or Maybe.

Secondly, that AMD build is stupid because he’s using 3 sticks of RAM on a board that’s clearly designed for 2 or 4 RAM sticks. Two of the sticks will run dual channel and the other will be running single channel. I would go with 4 or 8 GB’s of Corsair XMS because a binary number of sticks interact better with each other. Also, overkill on that single GFX, If you’re looking for bitchin’ graphics I’d get a different ASUS motherboard that would support a Crossfire setup and get two ~$400 cards. Go with a better case too, you’ll need the airflow. Antec 900 or 1200.[/quote]

Antec 900
Crossfire

HAHAHAHAHAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHHAHAH

I barely have enough room for a single, albeit long card, and even then I had to remove the optional fan for one of the harddrive bays and I can only fit 3 harddrives in or 4 if I do some fuckery with the cables.

item.title: AMD or Intel?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

RXVL:

You’ll never find the actual number 3 in binary.

Sure you will, 11.

That’s like saying you’ll never find the number 203 in decimal.

Read full topic

item.title: AMD or Intel?
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

RXVL:

Why would you go for 3 instead of 4? It’s just stupid.

are you serious? tri channel allows more memory bandwidth to the memory controller than dual does. having 4gb (2x2gb) is dual. 3gb (3x1gb) is tri.

thats like saying why not 6gb (3x2gb) over 4gb?

Read full topic

item.title: AMD or Intel?
item.dc:creator: @RXVL RXVL
item.description:
@RXVL wrote:

Why would you go for 3 instead of 4? It’s just stupid.

xEnt:

You are saying don’t buy the i7 build because of your theory?

Not saying don’t buy it, I’m just saying I wouldn’t.

Mopman:

Though I’m not sure what “3 is not a binary number” means (11?)

You’ll never find the actual number 3 in binary.

eczema3:

RXVL, are you under the impression that i7 means 7 cores? Because it doesn’t. i7’s only have 4 cores.

I’m not that retarded.

Read full topic

Now they throw three sticks of RAM into the equation, 3 is not a binary or base 2 number. It doesn’t make sense to me, everything I’ve learned about computing is based off two, it makes sense. Secondly, that AMD build is stupid because he’s using 3 sticks of RAM on a board that’s clearly designed for 2 or 4 RAM sticks. the other ones have higher speeds & tighter timings, you won’t need to worry about that stuff.

item.title: AMD or Intel?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:14, topic:344895”][quote author=Radeon link=topic=441271.msg3241949#msg3241949 date=1276998674]

Intel.

And at least for the Intel 1366 socket, it uses tri-channel memory, you may of well take advantage of that. 6GB is pretty much the norm for these type of builds anyway.

From what I’ve read, there’s no benefit of upgrading to DD3 except for future proofing. And considering that this is a CPU we’re talking about, upgrading is only going to be very long-term so an extra $300 doesn’t seem worth it.

I assume you don’t plan to upgrade this build again within the upcoming 5-6 years (i’m referring to that beast of a graphics card).

Not really, but the 5870 at least doesn’t seem like a beast of a graphics card. It gets like ~ 30fps on crysis at 1080p. The 5970 on the other hand is ~ 50fps on crysis. Crysis is pretty old now so how future-proof are these cards?

intel chips run hot. make sure cooling is decent.

I was told after-market cooling won’t be necessary?
[/quote]
stock cpu fans are just fine, anyone telling you that you need after market is scamming you[/quote]Stock cpu fans are great if you are into vuvuzela music. BZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZ

Read full topic

From what I’ve read, there’s no benefit of upgrading to DD3 except for future proofing. And considering that this is a CPU we’re talking about, upgrading is only going to be very long-term so an extra $300 doesn’t seem worth it.

I assume you don’t plan to upgrade this build again within the upcoming 5-6 years (i’m referring to that beast of a graphics card).

Not really, but the 5870 at least doesn’t seem like a beast of a graphics card. It gets like ~ 30fps on crysis at 1080p. The 5970 on the other hand is ~ 50fps on crysis. Crysis is pretty old now so how future-proof are these cards?

intel chips run hot. make sure cooling is decent.

I was told after-market cooling won’t be necessary?[/quote]
stock cpu fans are just fine, anyone telling you that you need after market is scamming you
